input: The collaborative robot can guarantee that it will keep running the cycle until a stop is requested.
reasoning: Gold is a strategic until: the cobot can ensure cycle_running holds up to the point stop_requested occurs (and stop_requested eventually occurs). Prediction has no coalition modality and instead states globally that whenever runCycle holds, in the next step stopRequested is false. This changes both the strategic aspect and the temporal meaning (no until, no guarantee of stop request, and different condition).

input: The robotic arm can guarantee that if the object is fragile, then it will never exceed a maximum force.
reasoning: Gold says the Arm can enforce: always, if the object is fragile then from then on it is always not over the force limit (nested G). Prediction drops the coalition/agent modality entirely and changes the temporal meaning to a single-step constraint (!X(maxForce)) rather than never exceeding the limit (G !force_over_limit), and also changes the proposition names.

input: The agricultural system can guarantee that if the soil is dry, then at the next step it will enable irrigation.
reasoning: The prediction changes the meaning: it uses X soil_dry as the condition instead of soil_dry, nests an extra coalition modality inside the implication, and shifts the temporal structure. The gold requires that whenever soil_dry holds now, the system can ensure irrigation_on in the next step.

input: The drone can guarantee that it will keep holding altitude until it receives a descend command.
reasoning: Gold states the Drone can enforce an until property: holding_altitude must hold continuously up to (and until) the point descend_command occurs. Prediction instead is a global implication G(HoldAltitude -> F ReceiveDescendCmd), which (i) does not require holding altitude to persist until the command, and (ii) requires that whenever holding altitude holds, a descend command will eventually be received—an extra, different liveness requirement. Temporal structure and meaning differ.

input: The security system can guarantee that it will keep monitoring until the threat is removed.
reasoning: Gold states a coalition ability: the SecuritySystem can enforce (monitoring U threat_removed), i.e., monitoring holds continuously until threat_removed occurs. Prediction drops the coalition modality, changes the structure to a conjunction of G(X monitors) and F(threat_removed), which is not equivalent to an until (it doesn’t require monitoring to hold up to removal, and it separately asserts eventual removal rather than being the until endpoint under the same strategy).

input: The logistics system can guarantee that sooner or later the delivery will be completed.
reasoning: Gold is an ATL strategic ability: <<LogisticsSystem>>F delivery_done. Prediction lacks the coalition operator entirely and instead states a universal temporal property G F CompleteDelivery (always eventually), which is stronger and not an ability claim. Predicate name also differs.

input: The smart city system can guarantee that if an intersection is congested, then at the next step it will retime the traffic lights.
reasoning: Prediction is not a semantically equivalent ATL formula: it omits the coalition/strategic modality (<<CitySystem>>), does not express the global implication G(congested -> X retimed), and instead uses non-ATL/ill-formed constructs (Congestion(X), X+1, R) with different meaning (involving a release-like operator and conjunction with ~Congestion at next step).

input: The collaborative robot can guarantee that if the safety barrier is on, then it will always remain stopped.
reasoning: Prediction omits the coalition <<Cobot>> and changes the temporal requirement: gold requires that whenever the barrier is on, the robot is stopped forever (G stopped), while prediction only requires being stopped in the next step (X stop). Also predicate differs (stopped vs stop).

input: The system can guarantee that if an intruder is detected, then at the next step it will send an alarm.
reasoning: Coalition/agent is wrong: gold attributes the guarantee to <<System>>, but prediction uses <<any>>. Even if predicates are aliases, changing the coalition changes the ATL ability statement.

input: The collaborative robot can guarantee that if a stop is requested, then at the next step it will stop moving.
reasoning: The prediction does not match the ATL structure of the gold formula. The gold is an ATL strategic modality for coalition <<Cobot>> with a global implication: G(stop_requested -> X stopped). The prediction lacks the correct <<Cobot>> coalition operator and instead uses unclear bracketed constructs (X[<<r>>, <<c>>->X[<<s>>->Stop]]) that do not correspond to the required implication with stop_requested and next-step stopped. Temporal/strategic structure and atomic propositions are not preserved.

input: The robotic arm can guarantee that if the gripper is closed, then sooner or later the object will be lifted.
reasoning: Prediction omits the coalition modality <<Arm>> and changes the temporal structure by adding an extra next-step X and placing G outside any agent ability. Gold requires the arm to ensure at all times: if gripper_closed then eventually object_lifted; prediction instead states globally that in the next state the implication holds, without attributing control to the arm.

input: The Mars rover can guarantee that sooner or later it will reach the sampling site.
reasoning: Gold states the Rover can ensure eventual reachability: <<Rover>>F at_sampling_site. Prediction is G X ReachSamplingSite, which lacks the coalition modality and requires reaching the sampling site at every next step globally, a much stronger and different temporal property than eventual reachability.

input: The system can guarantee that it will keep monitoring until the observation window ends.
reasoning: Gold is an ATL strategic until: <<System>>(monitoring U window_closed), meaning System can enforce monitoring continuously up to (and until) the window ends. Prediction is a non-strategic implication G monitoring -> F observationWindowEnds, which (1) drops the coalition ability <<System>>, (2) replaces the until requirement with an implication between global monitoring and eventual ending, and (3) does not require monitoring to hold until the end occurs. Thus the semantics differ.

input: The machine can guarantee that the system remains safe until cancellation is requested.
reasoning: Gold is an ATL strategic until: <<Machine>>(safe U cancel), meaning the Machine can enforce safety holding at least until cancel occurs. Prediction is a non-strategic LTL-style formula G(Safe -> F CancellationRequested), which instead says whenever Safe holds then eventually cancellation is requested; it lacks the coalition modality and changes the temporal meaning from an until safety guarantee to an eventual-cancellation property.

input: The industrial system can guarantee that sooner or later production will be completed.
reasoning: Gold states an ability of the industrial system: <<IndustrySystem>>F production_done. Prediction lacks the coalition modality entirely and instead asserts a universal property G F production_completed (always eventually), which is stronger and not an ability claim. Predicate name also differs (production_done vs production_completed) without clear aliasing.

input: The system and the teacher together can guarantee that sooner or later the student will be certified.
reasoning: Gold states the coalition {EduSystem, Teacher} can ensure eventual certification: <<EduSystem,Teacher>>F certified. Prediction instead requires globally that at every step, in the next state, the student has the ability to eventually certify: <<system,teacher>>G(X(<<student>>F certified)). This changes both the temporal structure (adds G and X) and the agent/coalition responsible for ensuring certification (shifts to student's ability), so it is not semantically equivalent.

input: The industrial system can guarantee that if a machine overheats, then at the next step it will shut down.
prediction: <<all Machines>> G (Machine_i overheats -> X Machine_i shuts_down)
reasoning: Coalition/agent set differs: gold attributes the guarantee to <<IndustrySystem>>, while prediction uses <<all Machines>>. Also the prediction quantifies over individual machines (Machine_i) rather than a single system-level overheating/shutdown proposition, changing the semantic subject of the implication.

input: The collaborative robot can guarantee that if a human enters the area, then at the next step it will reduce speed.
reasoning: Coalition/agent is wrong: the gold attributes the guarantee to <<Cobot>>, but the prediction uses <<human>>. The temporal/conditional structure is also mismatched: gold is G(human_in_area -> X speed_low), while the prediction talks about X(next <<robot>>) and a speed comparison (speed < prev) rather than the proposition speed_low triggered by human_in_area.

input: The surveillance system can guarantee that sooner or later it will archive the logs after the shift ends.
reasoning: Prediction does not match the gold meaning. Gold is an ability formula: <<System>>F logs_archived (the system can ensure logs are eventually archived). The prediction lacks the coalition modality, uses a different temporal structure (G X ... U ...), and even places ~ShiftEnd as the until condition, which contradicts 'after the shift ends' rather than ensuring archiving eventually after ShiftEnd.

input: The surveillance system can guarantee that if an intruder enters the area, then sooner or later it will detect the intruder.
reasoning: Prediction does not match the ATL structure: it drops the coalition ability operator <<System>> and instead uses plain G with an X, and it misuses <<intruder>> and <<surveillance system>> as if they were propositions/coalitions inside the formula. The gold requires <<System>>G(intruder_entered -> F intruder_detected); the prediction changes both agent attribution and temporal structure.
